title: Origins and Evolution of the Global RNA Virome
body:
The only universal gene among RNA viruses is the RNA-dependent RNA polymerase (RdRp). 23

We developed an iterative computational procedure that alternates the RdRp phylogenetic tree 24 construction with refinement of the underlying multiple sequence alignments. and their ultimate origins. The prospects of substantial progress appeared dim because of the 143 extreme sequence divergence among RNA viruses, which could amount to irrevocable loss of 144 evolutionary information. 145

Recent revolutionary developments in virus metagenomics (metaviromics) dramatically 146 expanded the known diversity of RNA viruses and provided an unprecedented amount of 147 sequence data for informed investigation into RNA virus evolution (11, 17, 37). The foremost 148 development was the massive expansion of the known invertebrate virome that was achieved 149 primarily through meta-transcriptome sequencing of various holobionts. The subsequent 150 phylogenetic analysis revealed previously unknown lineages of +RNA and -RNA viruses and 151 prompted reconsideration of high rank virus unifications, such as +RNA virus supergroups (14, 152 38-41). The RNA viromes of fungi and prokaryotes also underwent notable expansion albeit not 153 as massive as that of invertebrates (13, 42, 43) . 154

Here we reexamine the evolutionary relationships among and within the 3 Baltimore Classes 155 of RNA viruses through a comprehensive analysis of the available genomic and metagenomic 156 sequences. In particular, to build a phylogenetic tree of thousands of viral RdRps, we designed RdRp sequences (Data set S1) and 1,028 RT sequences organized in 50+2 clusters (50 clusters 180 of RdRps and 2 clusters of RTs; see Materials and Methods for details). This sequence set did 181 not include RdRps of members of the families Birnaviridae or Permutatetraviridae, distinct 182 groups of RNA viruses that encompass a circular permutation within the RdRp Palm domain 183 (46) and therefore could not be confidently included in the alignment over their entire lengths. 184 All rights reserved. The phylogenetic tree of RdRps and RTs (Data set S2 and Figure 1 ) was assembled from a 185 set of trees that represent three hierarchical levels of relationships. At the lowest level, full 186 complements of sequences from each cluster were used to construct cluster-specific trees. At the 187 intermediate level, up to 15 representatives from each cluster were selected to elucidate 188 supergroup-level phylogeny. At the highest level, up to 5 representatives from each cluster were 189 taken to resolve global relationships (Data set S3A and S4). The final tree (Data set S2) was 190 assembled by replacing the cluster representatives with the trees from the previous steps. 191

The large number and immense diversity of the viruses included in our analysis create 192 serious challenges for a systematic, phylogeny-based nomenclature of the identified evolutionary 193 lineages of RNA viruses. Many such lineages consist of viruses newly discovered by 194 metaviromics, are not yet formally classified by the International Committee on Taxonomy of 195 Viruses (ICTV), and therefore, cannot be assigned formal names. For the purpose of the present 196 work, we adopted a semi-arbitrary naming scheme using the following approach. 1) We use 197 taxon names that have been fully accepted by the ICTV as of March 2018 (47) whenever 198 possible. These names are recognizable through their capitalization and italicization and rank-199 specific suffixes (e.g., -virales for orders, -viridae for families). As is the common practice in 200 virus taxonomy, the officially classified members of each ICTV-approved taxon are referred to 201 via vernaculars (recognizable through their lack of capitalization and italicization). For instance, 202 the members of the ICTV-approved order Bunyavirales are called bunyaviruses, whereas those 203 of the family Tombusviridae are called tombusviruses. However, in this work, both taxon and 204 vernacular terms are to be understood sensu lato: if our analysis indicates certain viruses to be 205 members of or very closely related to an ICTV-established taxon, we consider them members of 206 that taxon despite the lack of current ICTV recognition. As a result, in our analysis, the order 207 All rights reserved. No reuse allowed without permission.

Rooting the phylogenetic tree, generated using PhyML (48), between the RTs and RdRps 217 resulted in a well-resolved topology of RNA viruses which the tree splits into 5 major branches, 218 each including substantial diversity of viruses ( Figure 1 ). 219

Branch 1: leviviruses and their eukaryotic relatives, namely, "mitoviruses", "narnaviruses" 220 and "ourmiaviruses" (the latter three terms are placed in quotation marks as our analysis 221 contradicts the current ICTV framework, which considers mitoviruses and narnaviruses members 222 of one family, Narnaviridae, and ourmiaviruses members of a free-floating genus Ourmiavirus); 223

Branch 2 ("picornavirus supergroup"): a large assemblage of +RNA viruses of eukaryotes, in 224 particular, those of the orders Picornavirales and Nidovirales, the families Caliciviridae, 225

Potyviridae, Astroviridae, and Solemoviridae, a lineage of dsRNA viruses including 226 partitiviruses and picobirnaviruses; and several other, smaller groups of +RNA and dsRNA 227 viruses. 228 All rights reserved. No reuse allowed without permission.

These replicons consist of a single RdRp gene (Fig.  299 2B) and replicate either in mitochondria or in the cytosol of the host cells, respectively, of fungal 300 and invertebrate hosts (the latter hosts were identified in metaviromic holobiont analyses) (14, 301 53) . Recently, the existence of plant "mitoviruses" has been reported although it is not known 302 whether these viruses reproduce in the mitochondria (54). The "narnavirus" RdRp is also the 303 ancestor of the RdRp of the expanding group of "ourmiaviruses" (Figure 2A ). "Ourmiaviruses" 304 were originally identified in a narrow range of plants, and genomic analysis revealed the 305 chimeric nature of these viruses, with a "narnavirus"-like RdRp but SJR-CPs and movement 306 proteins (MPs) which were apparently acquired from "picorna-like" and "tombus-like" viruses, 307 respectively (55). Use of metaviromics has led to the identification of numerous related viruses 308 associated with invertebrates, many of which encode distinct SJR-CP variants and some of which 309 acquired an RNA helicase ( Figure 2B and S2) (14) . Thus, the evolution of this branch apparently 310 involved the loss of the structural module of leviviruses, which yielded naked RNA replicons 311 that reproduced in the mitochondria of early eukaryotes. Apart from the SJR-CP, an apparently ancestral protein that is likely to be a shared derived 369 character (synapomorphy) of Branch 2 is a serine protease that is present in members of the order 370

Picornavirales (with the diagnostic substitution of cysteine for the catalytic serine), members of 371 the potyvirus-astrovirus clade, solemoviruses, alvernavirus, and nidoviruses ( Figure 3B and 372 S2B). As demonstrated previously, this viral protease derives from a distinct bacterial protease, 373

probably of mitochondrial origin, which is compatible with an early origin of Branch 2 in 374 eukaryotic evolution (31). 375

The reconstruction of protein gain-loss, together with the comparison of genome 376 architectures in this branch, reveal extensive rearrangements as well as gene and module 377 displacement ( Figure 3B and S2B). Branch 2 includes viruses with relatively long genomes and 378 complex gene repertoires (nidoviruses, potyviruses and many members of Picornavirales) along 379 with viruses with much shorter genomes and minimal sets of genes (astroviruses and 380 solemoviruses). Clearly, evolution of Branch 2 viruses involved multiple gene gains. Of special 381 note is the gain of 3 distinct helicases in 3 clades within this branch: superfamily 3 helicases 382 (S3H) in members of Picornavirales, superfamily 2 helicases (S2H) in potyviruses, and 383 superfamily 1 helicases (S1H) in nidoviruses ( Figure 3B and S2B). This independent, convergent 384 gain of distinct helicases reflects the trend noticed early in the study of RNA virus evolution, 385 namely, that most viruses with genomes longer than ~6 kb encode helicases, whereas smaller 386 ones do not. This difference conceivably exists because helicase activity is required for the 387 replication of longer RNA genomes (73). Another notable feature is the change of virion 388 All rights reserved. The next stage of the network analysis aims at detecting supermodules that are formed from 607 the primary modules via connecting genes. The supermodules of RNA viruses failed to attain 608 statistical significance due to the small number of shared genes but nevertheless, some notable 609 connections are revealed by this analysis. Specifically, 8 overlapping supermodules were 610 identified ( Figure 8C ). The largest and, arguably, most remarkable is a supermodule that 611 combines +RNA, dsRNA and -RNA viruses that share the capping enzymes, S1H (with the 612 exception of Reoviridae and Mononegavirales) and additional connector genes (e.g., the OTU 613 family protease) that link some of the constituent modules. The second largest supermodule 614 combines large subsets of viruses from the RdRp Branches 2 and 3 that are connected through 615 the SJR-CP and the chymotrypsin-like protease. Notably, such a merger seems to have occurred on 632 at least three other independent occasions in Branch 1 because several groups of invertebrate 633 holobiont "narnaviruses" and some "ourmiaviruses" encode distantly related SJR-CPs that 634 apparently were acquired from different groups of plant and animal viruses (Figure 7) . 635

No known prokaryotic viruses are classified in Branch 640 2 but it has been proposed that picobirnaviruses, for which no hosts have been reliably identified, 641 actually are prokaryotic viruses. This proposal is based on the conspicuous conservation of 642 functional, bacterial-type, ribosome-binding sites (Shine-Dalgarno sequences) in picobirnavirus 643 genomes (107, 108). Should that be the case, viruses of prokaryotes might be lurking among 644 totiviruses as well. Then, Branch 4 would stem from a prokaryotic ancestor avoiding the need to 645 invoke virus transfer from eukaryotes to prokaryotes to explain the origin of the cystoviruses. 646

We made an attempt to quantify the potential horizontal virus transfer (HVT) events in RNA 647 viruses that represent the 5 major branches of the RdRp tree. The leaves of the tree were labeled 648 with the known hosts, the entropy of the host ranges for each subtree was calculated, and the 649 resulting values were plotted against the distance from the root (Figure 9 ). By design, for all 650 branches, entropy (host diversity) drops from the maximum values at the root to zero at the 651 leaves. All branches show substantial host range diversity such that, for example, at half-distance 652 from root to leaves, all branches, except for Branch 1, retain at least half of the diversity (Figure  653 9). Furthermore, differences between the branches are substantial, with the highest entropy 654 observed in branches 4 (dsRNA viruses) and 5 (-RNA viruses). With all the caveats due to 655 potential errors and ambiguities in host assignment, this analysis strongly suggests that HVT 656 played an important role in the evolution of all major groups of RNA viruses. 657

We reasoned that this expansion of the 662 RNA virosphere could provide for an improved understanding of virus evolution. Although 663 further progress of metaviromics and enhanced phylogenomic methods will undoubtedly change 664 current ideas, we believe that some key aspects of RNA virus evolution are indeed coming into 665 focus. 666

The expanded diversity of RNA viruses combined with the iterative procedure for 667 phylogenetic analysis allowed us to obtain a tree of all RdRps and the most closely related RTs 668 in which the main branches are strongly supported and thus appear to be reliable (Figure 1 ). To 669 our knowledge, the picture of RNA virus evolution emerging from the tree has not been 670 presented previously. The tree seems to clarify the relationships between the 3 Baltimore Classes 671 of RNA viruses by revealing the nested tree structure in which dsRNA viruses evolved, on at 672 least two occasions, from +RNA viruses, whereas -RNA viruses evolved from a distinct group of 673 dsRNA viruses. 674

The derivation of -RNA viruses from dsRNA viruses is, arguably, the most unexpected 675 outcome of the present analysis, considering the lack of genes (other than the RdRp) shared by 676 these virus classes. Clearly, given that the primary evidence behind the derivation of -RNA 677 viruses from within dsRNA viruses comes from deep phylogeny, extreme caution is due in the 678 interpretation of this observation. However, the pronounced similarity between the 3D structures 679 of the RdRps of the -RNA influenza virus A and bacteriophage 6 dsRNA cystovirus (35) is 680 compatible with our findings. Further, because virtually no -RNA viruses are known in 681 prokaryotes or unicellular eukaryotes [with the single exception of "leischbuviruses" in parasitic 682 All rights reserved. The subsequent parallel capture of 708 different helicases enabled evolution of increasingly complex genomes via accumulation of 709 additional genes (Figure 10) . Notably, similar levels of complexity, with the complete coding 710 capacity of 20 to 40 kb, were reached independently in 4 branches of the RdRp tree, namely, 711

Branch 2 (coronaviruses), Branch 3 (closteroviruses and flaviviruses), Branch 4 (reoviruses), and 712

Gene exchange and shuffling of gene modules are important factors of RNA virus evolution. 714

For example, it appears that all dsRNA viruses in the two major clades within Branches 2 and 4 715 share homologous structural modules that combine with distinct RdRps. At least in the case of 716 partiti-picobirnaviruses in Branch 2, the dsRNA virus ("toti-like virus") CP apparently displaced 717 the ancestral SJR-CP. However, this particular protein structure does not seem to be essential to 718 encapsidate a dsRNA genome: birnaviruses, whose provenance is uncertain due to the 719 permutation in their RdRps, retain SJR-CP, which is most closely related to SJR-CP of 720 nodaviruses and tetraviruses (19). An even more striking example of module shuffling is 721 presented by amalgaviruses, dsRNA viruses that group with partitiviruses in the RdRp tree but 722 encode a distant homolog of the nucleocapsid protein of -RNA bunyaviruses (111-114). More 723 generally, structural and replication modules have been repeatedly shuffled during the evolution 724 of +RNA viruses. Examples include displacement of the ancestral SJR-CP by a filamentous CP 725 in potyviruses and by a helical nucleocapsid protein in nidoviruses, and multiple cases of 726 displacement with rod-shaped-like CP and unique nucleocapsid proteins in Branch 3. In addition to invertebrates that appear to be dominant HVT agents, fungi could also play an 763 important role in HVT within the global RNA virome. Indeed, fungi that are tightly associated 764 with plants and insects often share closely related viruses with these organisms (116-118). 765

Furthermore, an indisputable case of cross-kingdom transfer of an insect iflavirus to an 766 entomopathogenic fungus has been recently described (119). 767

These findings appear to be best compatible with a grand evolutionary scenario ( Figure 10 ) 768 in which the ancestor of the eukaryotic RNA virome was a levi/narnavirus-like naked RNA 769 replicon that originally reproduced in mitochondria and combined with a host carbohydrate-770 binding SJR protein (19) or a preexisting SJR-CP from a DNA virus to form a simple ancestral 771 virus. Given that viruses of Branches 2, 3, and 4 are present in modern protists, it appears likely 772 that these branches emerged in early eukaryotes. The expansion of the global RNA virome thanks to the advances of metaviromics, combined 790 with the phylogenomics results, seem to call for an overhaul of the current virus taxonomy on 791 multiple levels. Most importantly, creation of a coherent, hierarchical system with multiple 792 taxonomic ranks seems to be imminent. This process has already started with the proposal of a 793 phylum rank for -RNA viruses, for which monophyly is unequivocally supported by the present 794 analysis (Figures 1 and 6) .
